title: Interesting word logic problem
text:
A logic problem for LLMs

Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


The Stolen Key (created by GPT 4o)

Four friends‚ÄîAlex, Ben, Cara, and Dana‚Äîwere the only people in a locked house when the front door key went missing. Each of them made a statement:

Alex: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt take the key.‚Äù

Ben: ‚ÄúCara took the key.‚Äù

Cara: ‚ÄúDana is lying.‚Äù

Dana: ‚ÄúBen is lying.‚Äù

Only one of them is telling the truth. Who stole the key?


How do LLMs response to the prompt?

GPT4o
Let‚Äôs analyze the statements logically:

Only one person is telling the truth.
If Ben were telling the truth (‚ÄúCara took the key‚Äù), then all other statements must be false.

Alex saying ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt take the key‚Äù would be false ‚Üí meaning Alex did take the key. This contradicts Ben‚Äôs claim.
Therefore, Ben is lying.


Since Ben is lying, Cara did not take the key. That means we must find another truth-teller.

If Cara were telling the truth (‚ÄúDana is lying‚Äù), then:

Dana saying ‚ÄúBen is lying‚Äù would be false, meaning Ben is telling the truth.
But we already established that Ben was lying, so this contradicts our assumption.


Since Cara cannot be the truth-teller either, let‚Äôs check Dana.

If Dana were telling the truth (‚ÄúBen is lying‚Äù), then:

Ben‚Äôs statement (‚ÄúCara took the key‚Äù) is false ‚Üí meaning Cara did NOT take the key.
That makes Alex‚Äôs statement (‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt take the key‚Äù) false ‚Üí meaning Alex DID take the key.


Since this setup is consistent and only one truth-teller exists, the key was stolen by Alex.


GPT4o1
Answer: Alex took the key.
Here‚Äôs a quick way to see why:

Assume Dana is telling the truth (‚ÄúBen is lying‚Äù).
If Ben is lying, then ‚ÄúCara took the key‚Äù is false, so Cara did not take the key.
Because only one statement can be true, Alex‚Äôs and Cara‚Äôs statements must be false:

Alex‚Äôs statement ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt take the key‚Äù is false, so Alex did take the key.
Cara‚Äôs statement ‚ÄúDana is lying‚Äù is false, meaning Dana is indeed telling the truth.


All conditions are satisfied with Dana telling the truth and Alex as the thief.


Analysis of LLM Reasoning
This problem is an example of how LLMs process logical constraints. Given the one-truth constraint, LLMs systematically eliminate contradictions to arrive at a valid solution.
Notably, both GPT-4o and GPT-4o1 reached the same answer through slightly different reasoning:
GPT-4o used a step-by-step contradiction approach, testing each individual‚Äôs truthfulness and discarding inconsistencies. GPT-4o1 opted for a more streamlined deduction, assuming Dana‚Äôs truthfulness and resolving the logical consequences. This exercise highlights LLMs‚Äô ability to process deductive logic, truth-value constraints, and contradictions, making them effective at solving structured reasoning puzzles.
Would another LLM produce the same answer? Would performance change if the statements were reworded? Testing across different models could reveal nuances in AI logical reasoning and bias towards specific deduction styles.
What do you think‚Äîshould we test other AI models on this problem?

title: Third post about a math problem
text:
A teacher writes five numbers on the board:
3, 5, 9, 17, ?
She tells her students that the pattern follows a logical rule.
What number should replace the question mark (?) in the sequence?
Can you figure it out?
Solving the Pattern To determine the missing number, let‚Äôs analyze the pattern in the sequence:
3, 5, 9, 17, ?
We examine the differences between consecutive terms:
5 ‚àí 3 = 2
9 - 5 = 4
17 ‚àí 9 = 8
This gives us the difference sequence:
2, 4, 8
Observing this pattern, we see that each difference doubles the previous one:
2 , 4 , 8 , 16
Following this doubling pattern, the next difference should be 16.
Thus, the missing number in the sequence is:
17 + 16 = 33 17+16=33

title: Third post about a math problem
text:
GPT-4o‚Äôs Approach
GPT-4o follows a structured method to detect numerical patterns. It:
Identifies the differences between terms. Recognizes a doubling pattern in these differences. Extends the pattern logically to predict the next term. Computes the missing number using the established rule. üìå GPT-4o‚Äôs Answer: 33.

title: Third post about a math problem
text:
GPT-4o1‚Äôs Approach
GPT-4o1 arrives at the same conclusion using a similar approach:
It calculates the first-order differences: 2, 4, 8. It recognizes that each difference is doubling. It predicts the next difference as 16. It adds 16 to the last number (17) to find 33. üìå GPT-4o1‚Äôs Answer: 33.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
